children.value: A RealmQuery encapsulates a query on a
using the Builder pattern. The query is executed using either
The input to many of the query functions take a field name as String. Note that this is not type safe. If a RealmObject class is refactored care has to be taken to not break any queries.
is unordered, which means that there is no guarantee that querying a Realm will return the objects in the order they where inserted. Use
(String)} and similar methods if a specific order is required.
A RealmQuery cannot be passed between different threads.

Results are obtained quickly most of the times. However, launching heavy queries from the UI thread may result in a drop of frames or even ANRs. If you want to prevent these behaviors, you can instantiate a Realm using a
. This way queries will be forced to be launched from a non-UI thread. Alternatively, you can also use

Launching heavy queries from the UI thread may result in a drop of frames or even ANRs.
We do not recommend doing so and therefore it is not allowed by default.
If you want to prevent these behaviors you can obtain a Realm using a
. This way you will be forced to launch your queries from a non-UI thread, otherwise calls to this method will throw a
Finds all objects that fulfill the query conditions. This method is only available from a Looper thread.
Sorts the query result by the specific field name in ascending order.
Sorting is currently limited to character sets in 'Latin Basic', 'Latin Supplement', 'Latin Extended A', 'Latin Extended B' (UTF-8 range 0-591). For other character sets, sorting will have no effect.
the field name to sort by.
Sorts the query result by the specified field name and order.
Sorting is currently limited to character sets in 'Latin Basic', 'Latin Supplement', 'Latin Extended A', 'Latin Extended B' (UTF-8 range 0-591). For other character sets, sorting will have no effect.
the field name to sort by.
Sorts the query result by the specific field names in the provided orders.
is only used in case of equal values in
Sorting is currently limited to character sets in 'Latin Basic', 'Latin Supplement', 'Latin Extended A', 'Latin Extended B' (UTF-8 range 0-591). For other character sets, sorting will have no effect.
Sorts the query result by the specific field names in the provided orders. Later fields will only be used if the previous field values are equal.
Sorting is currently limited to character sets in 'Latin Basic', 'Latin Supplement', 'Latin Extended A', 'Latin Extended B' (UTF-8 range 0-591). For other character sets, sorting will have no effect.
an array of field names to sort by.
how to sort the field names.

Selects a distinct set of objects of a specific class. When multiple distinct fields are given, all unique combinations of values in the fields will be returned. In case of multiple matches, it is undefined which object is returned. Unless the result is sorted, then the first object will be returned.
first field name to use when finding distinct objects.
remaining field names when determining all unique combinations of field values.
Limits the number of objects returned in case the query matched more objects.
Note that when using this method in combination with
they will be executed in the order they where added which can affect the end result.
This predicate will never match, resulting in the query always returning 0 results.
Create a text-based predicate using the Realm Query Language. This predicate can be combined with other raw or type safe predicates, it accepts Realm values as arguments.
Class and property names used in the raw predicate can be either the names defined in the Realm Model classes or the internal names defined using the
annotations. If a class or property name contains spaces those must be escaped.

Arguments are defined in the string predicate as $argument_index, where $argument_index is a decimal integer that specifies the position of the argument in the argument list. The first argument is referenced by $0, the second by $1, etc.
for a more detailed description of the Realm Query Language.
instance to which this query belongs.
on the returned instance is discouraged as it is the same as calling it on the original Realm instance which may cause the Realm to fully close invalidating the query.
Returns a textual description of this query.
Returns the internal Realm name of the type being queried.
Finds the first object that fulfills the query conditions.
Launching heavy queries from the UI thread may result in a drop of frames or even ANRs.
We do not recommend doing so, but it is allowed by default.
If you want to prevent these behaviors you can obtain a Realm using a
. This way you will be forced to launch your queries from a non-UI thread, otherwise calls to this method will throw a
but runs asynchronously on a worker thread. An listener should be registered to the returned
to get the notification when query completes. The registered listener will also be triggered if there are changes made to the queried
is deleted, the listener will be called one last time and then stop. The query will not be re-run.
